reviews.content: It's one of the best westerns ever made. Maybe it's not so exciting to watch it today than it was 36 years ago but it still makes my eyes lock on the screen. There's only one western better than that and it's "The Unforgiven".
reviews.heading: One of the best westerns ever made.

reviews.content: I saw this movie along time ago when I was just a little kid and I thought it was boring compared to The Good the Bad and the Ugly. But I decided to watch it again a few weeks ago and I dont know what I was thinking. The movie is a masterpiece ( as gritty as it may seem ). The movie far outshines most of American westerns. Lee Van Cleef is great as veteran bounty killer and the same goes to Clint Eastwood. Gian Volante puts up a good performance as the evil Indio. The plot is a little slow but look at "High Noon" or any of the other old westerns. My point being is that they're all slow and this one moves fast compared to the rest. An all time great western!!
reviews.heading: "This train 'll stop at Tocumcari

reviews.content: Hardly a sentimental note to the whole film. About a criminal "Indio" and two bounty hunters who pursue him. One is revealed to have a very personal interest in killing this particular criminal (i.e. revenge).There is very little sentimentality in this; however this does not detract from it being a very very entertaining and fun. In my opinion it is the best of the Sergio Leone films ("The Good, The Bad and the Ugly" grates a little on re-viewing; "A fistful of dollars" is too claustrophobic (script-wise) and predictable; "A few dollars more" has more scope, and a very mean attitude to boot). Unlike many other westerns that are highly rated on IMDB (aside from "Once Upon a Time in the West" which is also brilliant), this film is virtually purely focussed on the actions and inter-play of 3 intelligent and violent men; No romance, virtually no sentimentality, and great entertainment. Great Western. 9/10.
reviews.heading: Excellent hard nosed stuff...

reviews.content: This film has to be the best Western ever made. The hard, often brutal lifestyle of the those who lived and worked in the days of the 'Wild West' is brilliantly portrayed in this film. It is ironic perhaps that this film was made by outsiders, ie non-Americans. Up until the 'spaghetti westerns', American made films of this period, tended to put too much gloss on the film, portraying like as hard work but at the same time, romantic and cosy. Sergio Leonne with a neutral and rational frame of mind, directs the film with the truth slant that this historic period deserves. The best of the 'Spaghetti' series, (The Good, the Bad and the Ugly) is rather too slowly paced, 'A Fistful of Dollars' will be as entertaining in 50 years time as it is now.
reviews.heading: Ironic that the best Westerns are made by outsiders.

reviews.content: the best ever western movie, there will never be a movie like that again.THE MUSIC , the music it is amazing , van cleef and the pipe and clint also. this movie will never ever die.
reviews.heading: THE BEST EVER

reviews.content: All three of the films in the Dollars trilogy are excellent and this is the best of an outstanding lot. The title sequences with an incredible Morricone score stick in your mind. The music in certain sequences sticks in your mind, such as "La Resa Di Conti" where Indio confronts Tomaso in the old church (it's unusual the use of an organ in music for a western). The music where Colonel Douglas Mortimer strikes a match off the Hunchback's braces is very similar to the music Morricone wrote for "The Untouchables" apart from the twangs on the Jew's harp. It is used for a few other scenes with the Hunchback such as outside the El Paso bank and the confrontation with Colonel Mortimer in the taberna in Agua Caliente. The music is faintly reminiscent of Mussorgsky's "The Gnome" from "Pictures at an Exhibition". Apart from the music another reason I like the film is the scenery. Some of the mountains in a few scenes are reminiscent of Scotland. There are a few Scottish mountains bear a likeness to the Spanish mountains seen behind Manco. An absolutely unique western, better than many American ones.
reviews.heading: Best of The Dollars Trilogy

reviews.content:
Per Qualche Dollaro in Piu/For a Few Dollars More(1965) is much better than Sergio Leone's previous outing of A Fistful of Dollars(1965), and longer in duration. The first twenty minutes of For a Few Dollars More(1965) are well executed and one of the genre's best opening moments. The prison escape of Indio is done with great detail and precise filmmaking skill. Unlike the last film, there is more importantance on the characters of the movie. In the first dollar film, the gunfights were quick and short. In this movie everything slows down while a duel is about to commence.
Although Clint Eastwood is acknowledged as the star of the movie, its Lee Van Cleef to which the story puts the main focus on. Lee Van Cleef plays a man whose out for revenge against Indio for a tragedy from the past. The duel during the film's climatic moment is both intense and suspenseful. In both For a Few Dollars More(1965) and Once Upon a Time in the West(1969), there is a tune from an object that represents something from the past. There are a few similarities between Lee Van Cleef's Colonel Mortimer and Franco Nero's Django. As in Once Upon a Time in the West(1969), the use of flashback occurs in the picture at a critical moment.
Sergio Leone really had improved as a filmmaker when you view For a Few Dollars More(1965). Clint Eastwood shows a mysterious presence with his characterization of Monco. Ennio Morricone conducts a score of excellent quality with a haunting melody from the pocket watch. Klaus Kinski gives a stand out performance in basically a short role. Lee Van Cleef portrays a man of experience and maturity. The director's assistant directors were two guys who were later become big names during the 1970's named Fernando Di Leo and Tonino Valerii.
reviews.heading: Improvement Over A Fistful of Dollars(1964)

reviews.content: FAFDM is a considerable improvement over the original Fistfull Of Dollars both for director Leone and rising star Eastwood.Brimmed with confidence from FOD Leone becomes slightly more stylish & extrovert with his choice of directing. The violence and the dry humour is still there but the camera seems to pan out a whole lot more while the characters have more time to evolve into something more tangible than from FOD.We can also see from this film Leone's gradual development into producing more than just a shoot-out western. Very gradually each scene seems to have a rhythm & mood all of its own that somehow doesn't seem right for a typical western. But Leone wants to move us away from this typical norm and educate us a little further so that our idea of a western is no longer imagined on the lines of High Noon or The Searchers. Leone is perhaps one of only a dozen decent directors who has the talent & imagination to use the musical score to either enhance a scene or generate more pathos from it. Here he uses this technique only sparingly (the pocket watch duel being the prime example of this). And yet by the time he directed Once Upon A Time in the West, Morricone's haunting score is used more & more frequently to further enhance & emotionally charge the scene in question.FAFDM is quite good for what it is, but lacks a certain clarity & direction, which isn't a complaint as such but perhaps Leone was trying for too many new ideas concurrently while living off a meagre budget. Although to be fair he soon repairs the damage in the third and best of the Dollar westerns where he is given the time & money to live out his ideas to the full.As for Eastwood, well he still doesn't get round to saying very much which although doesn't hurt his kinetic performance it does make him a trifle wooden & staid at times. Van Cleef gives a more pointed & emotional performance as the elder bounty hunter of the two and perhaps takes the overall honours in the film. Overall For a Few Dollars More can be seen more as a development post for Leone's considerably crafted talents. It's also quite a good western but it might be an idea to give this a miss and move on to the superior Good, Bad & the Ugly.***/*****
reviews.heading: Leone, makes my day once again!

reviews.content: My favorite movie of all time, more than fifty viewings, each one better than the last, as all elements erupt in simple power, from desolate desert to marauding music to hard men in dusty boots with mean guns, all bravado cut lean across Clint and Indio and Lee Van Cleef whose lives are boiled to the basics of greed and violence where the blood runs between life and death.
reviews.heading: Classy Classic in Wild West of Spain

reviews.content: Before giving a comment, let me introduce the film to the readers: in 1964, Italian Director Sergio Leone made `A Fistful Of Dollars' starring Clint Eastwood and (the gorgeous!) Gian Maria Volonté. A year later, Leone made `For A Few Dollars More', and, in 1966, his masterpiece `The Good, The Bad and the Ugly'. The 3 films are known as `the so-called Dollars trilogy'.I watched the films in the wrong order, but I must say that FAFDM is an archetypal `Spaghetti Western', a genre characterized by a deceivingly simple plot, few but ironic lines, absurd coincidences, and intense violence. In FAFDM, Gian Maria Volonté and Lee Van Cleef gave a stunning performance, the former as a psychotic criminal, the latter as a cynical bounty killer. And, in the middle, the laconic man with no name (Clint Eastwood), another bounty killer, pairs up with either of the other two, depending on his interest.The soundtrack of that film, provided by the creative Ennio Morricone, was cleverly used to match the scenes. Watch out for the scene from the past where Volonté rapes Van Cleef's sister, and for the crosscutting between Van-Cleef's eyes and Volonté's face in his wanted' portrait. And Eastwood counts Volonté's men in terms of how much money their heads are worth!That film is rather long, but highly creative and entertaining. I've watched it 3 times and will watch it a 100 times again.If you're looking for THE Spaghetti Western, `For A Few Dollars More' would be it. And, trust me, you should own all three films, like I do, and their breathtaking soundtracks
reviews.heading: THE ARCHETYPAL SPAGHETTI WESTERN

reviews.content: Holding the centre between the compressed hysteria of A FISTFUL OF DOLLARS and the epic baroque of THE GOOD THE BAD AND THE UGLY, FOR A FEW DOLLARS MORE is a muted, slow-burning puzzle. Don't get me wrong, it's still full of funny and madness, but there are few explosions of ecstatic violence, the rites here are most definitely those of death, a death which infects the whole land, as visualised in the hilarious, absurd opening scene, a fixed long shot of a lonely rider who is arbitrarily picked off. Life has no value in these parts. If FISTFUL was early Verdi, than this is Wagner, an astonishingly free consolidation and elaboration of themes, intricately worked out, a fusion of visual and musical leitmotifs, true music drama. If Peckinpah is balletic, than this is a suffocating tableau vivant (or mourant?).All the compelling contradictions and paradoxes of the Leone aesthetic are in full fruitful disjunction here. The tension between seriousness and mockery - on the one hand the film is given epic dignity and mythic scope. The haphazard nature of the sets might seem 'artificial', but so were settlements in those days, Leone giving the lie to manifest destiny. There is a quest, in keeping with the great Westerns (eg THE SEARCHERS), linked to family.On the other hand, the film is laced with parodic camp. Morricone's magnificent score is at its most unleashed here, comically intrusive at moments of apparent solemnity. The gleeful homoeroticism (eg Indio lighting his cigar from Monco's; the uproarious hat shootout, the hat being a traditional emblem of male sexual power; Mortimer's yummy fetishistic leather boots), undermines the macho posturing, in Monco's case again linked to sexual abstinence. The film is full of bizarre one-liners, double-takes that seem addressed to the audience, berserk compositions, angles and editing, vaudevillian bits of business that constantly distract us from the issue at hand. And what that issue might be is obfuscated until the closing ritual, a dress rehearsal for UGLY's astonishing finale, so that it is easy to be distracted. The motif of the tinkling watches is, typically, as silly as it is evocative.Further, there is a great emphasis on the theatrical, which wrenches the viewer out of the action at hand, into a consideration of role playing. Mortimer is pure theatre, as he makes his entrance from the stopped train, the proscenium arch of the carriage, or has his own musician scoring his actions in the first saloon scene.Nothing fits in MORE This is Leone's most dreamlike film, as his lonely ciphers travel back and forth over a vast, empty terrain, like dream figures. Even sites of potential life - saloons, trains, brothels etc. - are eerily underpopulated, and if the settlements they arrive in aren't ghost towns, they are when they leave. The film is full of circular dream logic, random, elliptical - the final exit of Monco carting the dead is brilliantly surrealist.And yet, the film is vividly tangible in a way traditional Westerns never were (except maybe Mann, Leone's most obvious influence): you can feel the creaking wood, the interior decor, the sun-parched land - Leone's style, describing a world of Darwinian viciousness yet geometrically beautiful, deliberately intrudes on people and things, as if the camera is about to touch them.Once again, these contradictions converge on Clint's character. He is, as in FISTFUL, seemingly an abstract figure, an inviolable Grim Reaper shearing his way through Biblically arid lands. Even as the film progresses, and relationships are forged, Monco remains an enigma. Mortimer is linked to family, Indio to his friends - both relations are characterised by rupture and betrayal, motivating their actions. Monco has none, not even the tantalising intimation given in FISTFUL.But, in contrast to his abstraction or distance, his very human vulnerability is revealed in a ritualistic beating, as in the first film; his beautiful body pulverised, on public display. His gaze is less powerful in this film, less organising, as you might expect when he is on the sidelines to a quest he doesn't understand. His expert gunplay is less inexplicable, 'supernatural'.He also seems the most human of the three (that Leone triangle again); he is no longer the mysterious stranger in the series - this is Mortimer, whose unaccountable activities, aquiline face and morose hauteur are as unlikely to endear as Indio's strange, mentally befuddling, neurosis. That these latter are linked through family, past and death, against Monco is significant, but there might also be another opposition between 'old man' Mortimer, with his traditional, if more TERMINATOR-like, revenge quest, and 'boy' Monco's pointless capitalism, the Old West and the New (although Mortimer is linked to trains, which are shown, in a wonderful scene with a stubborn old landowner, to be the phantom power indifferent to these boy-boy rituals - soon to be dramatised in Leone's masterpiece). This is taken to a surprising conclusion in the mighty final part of the trilogy.
reviews.heading: One of the great sequels.(possible spoiler)

reviews.content: One of my favorite movie lines of all time as spoken by Klaus Kinski upon recognizing Lee Van Cleef in the little cantina as the one who used his (Klaus') cheek to strike his match earlier in the movie. When Kinski ask if he "remember me, amigo," Van Cleef just reply "uh uh." To which he's asked to try that trick again, which prompts Van Cleef to utter another one of my all time lines - "I generally don't smoke 'til after I've eaten; why don't you come back in five minutes." Just typing this brings smiles to my face. I've been a Lee Van Cleef fan since High Noon (with Robert Wilke) and Kansas City Confidential (with Jack Elam and Neville Brand!) and this was/is the movie that made him a star. Granted it didn't last for long, but he did have his 15 minutes. This is my favorite Spaghetti Western, it was also my first (didn't see "Fistful" until much later - and Good, Bad, Ugly was a major disappointment - I wanted Van Cleef to play the same role). And the music, especially the pipe organ, just blows my mind. Highly enjoyable; think I'll go and watch it again.
reviews.heading: Well, well; if it isn't the smoker. Well...

reviews.content: "For A Few Dollars More" is the second of the trio of westerns made in Italy starring Clint Eastwood and produced by Sergio Leone. This film has Clint portraying a bounty hunter of the old school-no partners, all for me-who ends up joining forces with a mysterious man in black, Colonel Mortimer, played by Lee Van Cleef. The two of them are hunting a vicious Mexican outlaw, El Indio, played by Gian Maria Volonte. Each has a distinct reason for wanting to capture the bandit; Clint has $10,000 dollars bounty money in mind, while Van Cleef is simply wanting to extract a personal degree of revenge upon the bandit.In the course of the film, the two actually join the gang, help pull off a bank robbery, then spend the time plotting how to get the gang members bumped off and collect the bounties on a whole passel of bad guys. Ultimately, the final shootout does occur with Van Cleef and Volonte staring each other down and Eastwood awaiting the outcome.A rather violent view of the west, but then, the characters portrayed were rather violent men, interested in personal revenge or "For A Few Dollars More." A film favorite for those fans of Clint Eastwood, and a 9/10 on my personal scale.
reviews.heading: The Man with No Name is joined by the Man in Black to hunt for a bounty of dollars.

reviews.content: Having taken his cue from High Noon, Leone fashioned a true revisionism of the western genre while at the same time establishing a sort of standard in the process as displayed in Fistful of Dollars. Most viewers rate The Good the Bad and the Ugly as the superior of the "Dollars Trilogy," but I think a keen eye might spot For a Few Dollars More as the more compactly entertaining and indeed, more fully realized of the trio. Morricone's haunting score (as recognised in the pocket watch's melody) and Leone's attention to an evocative mise-en-scene combine together with a plot that moves the viewer from title to end with (dark)humor, tension and finally beauty. A ballet of sorts. And did I mention that Lee and Clint are completely badass?
reviews.heading: Arguably the "best" of the Dollars Trilogy

reviews.content: The second in the 'dollars' trilogy is by far a better movie than 'A Fistful of Dollars' The story about two bounty killers forming a partnership to catch a bandit may sound run of the mill but the performances of the actors and the direction as well as the music make this film a superb cinematic experience. The film involves one of the bounty killers (Eastwood) infiltrating the band of desperadoes in order to get their hands on the bounty on their heads while the other bounty killer (Van Cleef) follows his every move just in case he decides to leave him out of there 'deal'. What follows is a series of bank holdups, jailbreaks and the film climaxes with a stand off between the bounty killers and the evil bandit Indio. Two scenes to watch out for are the match striking scene with the hunchback and when the Bounty killers first meet face to face. This film is a must see for all Western fans.
reviews.heading: Bravo
